awd_titl_txt: Evaluating the Potential of Community College Guided Pathways Reforms to Increase Undergraduate STEM Student Success
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest in maintaining a well-educated, diverse STEM workforce.  To do so, it focuses on understanding how to increase the capacity of community colleges to broaden participation and success in undergraduate STEM programs.  Almost two million first-time college students enroll in community colleges each year.  Unfortunately, few of these students successfully complete an associate or bachelor's degree in STEM. The structural organization of most community colleges does not provide critical supports that could improve STEM success.  For example, they generally lack the structural organization needed to help students consider STEM careers or to align students' coursework and learning experiences with STEM career demands. Consequently, efforts to improve community college student access and success in STEM must address these structural barriers.  However, hundreds of community colleges are fundamentally redesigning programs, policies, and practices at scale to better help students choose and complete STEM programs suited to their interests and talents. They are doing this by: (1) creating clear "program maps" to completion, transfer, and careers in fields such as sciences, engineering, and computer science; (2) helping new students explore career and college options and develop a full-program academic plan; (3) monitoring students' progress to help them stay on their plan; and (4) ensuring that students are building essential skills and knowledge across programs. This project, is designed to evaluate how these whole-college "guided pathways" reforms are changing practices in STEM programs. 

The project team will partner with higher education agencies in three states that are leading statewide community college Guided Pathways reforms: Ohio, Tennessee, and Washington. The goals of the project are to evaluate how these Guided Pathways reforms are changing practices in STEM programs, advising, and other supports; what barriers and facilitators college and STEM program leaders face in implementing these reforms; what metrics colleges should use to formatively evaluate the effects of these reforms on STEM program effectiveness; and what relationship exists between Guided Pathways reforms and enrollment, early progress, and persistence in undergraduate STEM programs by community college students generally and by underrepresented students in particular. The research design is based on a mixed methods approach that will include field research to assess the scale of implementation of Guided Pathways reforms, statistical analysis of student unit records, and qualitative analysis of interview and focus group data. Resulting analyses will be the basis of practitioner-focused reports and briefs and peer-reviewed journal articles.  The study is designed to inform college practices and public policy through the identification and validation of metrics.  The project team will produce a practitioner guide that includes metrics that for formative use to evaluate the effects of Guided Pathways reforms on STEM outcomes.  The team will also produce a practitioner guide on how community colleges can leverage ongoing community college Guided Pathways reforms to improve access to and completion of undergraduate STEM programs. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.  Through the Institutional and Community Transformation track, the program supports efforts to transform and improve STEM education across institutions of higher education and disciplinary communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This three-year project examined the adoption and effectiveness of whole-college “Guided Pathways” (GP) reforms—which are being adopted by hundreds of community colleges nationally—in improving outcomes for students, with a particular focus on students who are underrepresented in STEM education and careers. This project, which was conducted in partnership with higher education agencies from three states, evaluated which GP practices colleges are adopting at scale, what metrics colleges should use to formatively evaluate the effects of these reforms on STEM program effectiveness; and what the relationship is between GP reforms and early progress and persistence by community college students generally and by underrepresented students in particular.

Adoption of Guided Pathways Reforms. In 2022, we administered an institutional survey to 69 colleges in Ohio, Tennessee, and Washington to assess the “scale of adoption” of 14 GP reforms across four areas of practice. Among the 63 colleges that completed the survey, we found 19 high adopter colleges (that adopted 9+ practices), 29 medium adopters (5-8 practices), and 15 low adopters (4 or less practices). Colleges were most likely to have scaled the practices of mapping pathways in career-technical education and transfer programs and identifying key math pathways within those maps. Adoption patterns were unique to each state. In Ohio, at least half of the colleges scaled processes for monitoring students’ progress and had implemented course improvement strategies in foundational program courses. All colleges in Tennessee had scaled corequisite math, and most also scaled advising processes. While all practices were less likely to have been scaled in Washington, colleges there made progress in early advising by implementing a caseload-by-field model and encouraging early foundational course-taking. Colleges in Tennessee made the most progress adopting pathways practices at scale, which is not surprising since Tennessee started GP reforms in 2014, two to three years before colleges in Ohio and Washington.

STEM Program Momentum Metrics. Using administrative records from transfer-intending students from three states to develop indicators of early STEM program momentum, we found that first-year completion of a calculus course and first-year completion of a science, technology, or engineering course specified on statewide STEM transfer pathways are reliable indicators of subsequent STEM transfer and bachelor’s degree attainment across a wide range of state and institutional contexts. These two metrics are strong predictors of success among subgroups of students by race/ethnicity and gender. The study's findings provide support for the use of the STEM momentum metrics to formatively evaluate reforms aimed at strengthening STEM transfer outcomes and closing equity gaps in STEM bachelor’s degree attainment.

Evaluation of Guided Pathways Reforms. Drawing on GP adoption data from the institutional survey and administrative records from 2010-2020 for more than 800,000 students in Ohio, Tennessee, and Washington, researchers examined the association between adopting GP practices and early student momentum. We focused on four indicators of early momentum: 1) college-level credits earned in the first year; 2) college-level math credits earned in the first year; 3) college-level STEM credits earned in the first year; 4) fall-to-fall persistence.

In Tennessee, improvements in early student momentum were observed after the introduction of GP reforms, specifically in college-level credits earned in the first year and in fall-to-fall persistence. On their own, some specific GP practices may benefit early student outcomes, while others may hinder them. For example, corequisite college math was positively associated with college-level credits earned in the first year in Tennessee and Washington, while math pathways were associated with substantial increases in college-level math credits earned in the first year across all three states. By contrast, mapping career-technical programs and mandatory educational planning were, by themselves, negatively correlated with persistence (though the effects were small). Adopting reforms across GP practice areas was associated with larger improvements in early academic success than in any single practice area or the intensity of GP adoption. The most substantial positive association with college-level credits earned were associated with the simultaneous adoption of practices in Area One (clarifying paths to student end goals) and Area Three (keeping students on a path to completion). In Tennessee, this combination resulted in a twofold increase compared to the adoption of any single significant practice or to the moderate- or high-intensity adoption of practices. The combination of adopting practices in Areas One, Two (helping students get on a program path), and Three was positively associated with improvements in math and STEM credits earned in Tennessee and with student persistence in Washington. Ohio colleges achieved more significant gains in the number of college-level credits earned by adopting multiple practices within Area Three, as opposed to simultaneous adoption across different areas.

Project Publications and Presentations. This project produced 1 peer-reviewed article, three working papers, 1 report, and 2 briefs all available at ccrc.tc.columbia.edu. CCRC researchers presented findings at 15 national and state conferences to policymakers, researchers, and community college practitioners.


Last Modified: 01/26/2024
Modified by: Paul D Jenkins

This project, which was conducted in partnership with higher education agencies from three states, evaluated which GP practices colleges are adopting at scale, what metrics colleges should use to formatively evaluate the effects of these reforms on STEM program effectiveness; and what the relationship is between GP reforms and early progress and persistence by community college students generally and by underrepresented students in particular.
